What is the difference between the architecture of North and South Indian temples?

In short North Indian temples are built based on Nagara style of architecture(temples above Vindhya mountains) while South Indian temples are based on Dravidian style of architecture.(Below Vindhya mountains).There are also vesara style of temples in South India which is a combination of both Nagara style and Dravidian style.

But there are many different styles under these two main styles on which our Hindu temples were constucted.

Depending upon the place and regions,these styles differ.

Even Kings of every kingdom constructed there own style of Temples.

Lets see each Temple style one by one.I am

In short North Indian temples are built based on Nagara style of architecture(temples above Vindhya mountains) while South Indian temples are based on Dravidian style of architecture.(Below Vindhya mountains).There are also vesara style of temples in South India which is a combination of both Nagara style and Dravidian style.

But there are many different styles under these two main styles on which our Hindu temples were constucted.

Depending upon the place and regions,these styles differ.

Even Kings of every kingdom constructed there own style of Temples.

Lets see each Temple style one by one.I am only including 10 most important styles of architecture.But there are more architectural styles of various kingdoms.

1.Chalukya style of Temples(Dravidian style).

Chalukya Dynasty ruled mainly in South India.Our two eyes are not enough to witness the beauty of their temples.Very important are the pattadakal,Badami and Aihole temples(Unesco world heritage sites) of karnataka

Pattadakal,Karnataka

2.Hoysala style of Temples(Dravidian style)

Hoysala dynasty also ruled parts of South India,mainly the regions of present Mysore and Bangalore and adjacent areas.There temple constuction had many intricate designs and scupltures.

Belur and Halebidu have really gorgeous http://temples.Do visit.

3.Chola style of Temples(Dravidian style)-Their glory of rule extends whole of South India till south east asian countries.

One sentence to describe their temple glory- The Cholas conceived like giants and finished like jewellers.

The Great living Chola temples are recognized as UNESCO world heritage sites.

Tanjavur Small temple

Darasuram chariot temple,Tamil Nadu

Tanjavur Periya temple,Tamil Nadu

Note the top Vimana of the big temple is carved out of single stone that weighs 80 tons(80000 kgs).It is placed at a height of 66m.

4.Vijayanagara style(Dravidian style)

Well this majestic dynasty also ruled whole of South India.The kings of this great dynasty really stopped the invading Muslim rulers into South.

Even many temples in Hampi comes under UNESCO world heritage sites.

Single stone chariot-Virupaksha temple,Karnataka

If this great Kingdom was not there,even our South Indian temples would have been destroyed.Not only that this kingdom was defeated only by the combination of three muslim kingdoms.

Musical pillars,Hampi

Nothing can match the beauty of the temples constructed by the Vijayanagara rulers .The musical notes of their musical pillars are really amazing.Now only few monuments remain.

5.Kerala temples.

Kerala temples are very different than the other dravidian temples which follows Tantric rituals while all other temples of south follow Agama rituals.

Vadukkunathan temple,Kerala

6.Rock cut Style Temples(Dravidian style and Vesara style)-This type of temples are present all over South India.

These temples were either cut out of huge rocks or into large mountain faces.This style makes our Indians to be greatest architects,sculptors and engineers.

Eg:-Ellora and Ellora caves,Kailasanathar temple,Mahabalipuram rock cut temples,Badami temples.

Kailasanathar temple,Maharashtra.

Shore Temple,Mamallapuram,TN-Built by pallavas

7.Northern styles-Nagara style

Many famous temples have been destroyed by the Muslim rulers but somee were renovated ,others left and some temples still they are trying to build.

Notable ones are:-

Somnath Temple-This famous temple was destroyed 5 times(I think more times) by Muslim rulers-Arabs,Afghans,Turks,etc.After each time of destruction it was again built.

Somnath Temple

Lingaraj Temple,Orissa

Akshardam Temple

Sun Konark Teple,Orissa

8.Jain style-Jain temples were construrted by the followers of Jain religion.This type of temples can be found all over India.

Most famous is Dilwara temple,Shravana belagola temple,Kujaraho Temples,etc

Khujaraho Jain Temple

9.Gupta style(Nagara style).

The temples of Gupta dynasty are completely wiped out and only some small remples remain.We can only imagine what Mountain like temples of Kanauj and Mathura .

One famous thing is the Gupta iron pillar-The pillar is 8m tall and weighs 60 http://tons.It was cast of pure wrought iron and amazingly not rusted for nearly 1700 years.

Truth is this iron pillar was built by Guptas

10.Buddhist style Stupas-Built by Buddhists and thekings who followed Buddhism.

Famous one is Sanchi stupa.Like our Hindu temples,their temples were also destroyed.

Buddha stupa built by Ashoka

I am a North Indian girl. I went on a trip to Tamil Nadu last year. I visited Madurai, Tiruchirapalli, Mahabalipuram, Rameshwaram, Thanjavur, Kanyakumari and Chennai. These places are tranquil and peaceful in it's own way like every North Indian temples and spiritual places.

I want to share an incident from my trip which I feel I liked the most in Tamil Nadu than other states.

I visited Vivekananda's Rock Memorial at Kanyakumari, the sunrise point of Kanyakumari. The scene is worth watching from there.

At the Rock Memorial, I was sitting at a lonely place and excitingly watching waves formed by the ocean. The scene was enchanting.

Amidst my excitement, came three tall, muscular and body builder Tamil men. They stood beside me and asked for a selfie with them. I got scared and my brain started thinking that if I deny, their men's ego can be hurt and they can be harsh to me.

But by instinct I denied the selfie. My reply was No. Listening to my reply they gave me a smile and went away from there.

They were all muscular. They could have threatened me because I was standing alone there. So what I liked the most was they waited for my consent and when I declined the proposal for selfie, they respected my denial and just left that place so that i couldn't feel insecure.

Being a North Indian girl, I can recall one more incident which made me feel TN a safe place for girls.

When I was travelling back from Kanyakumari to Trichy by train, my mother and I were the only ladies in the bogie, everyone else were men. I found no one ogling at us in a bizarre way. They indulged in doing their own work. I found ourselves safe and secure in the bogie.

Apart from safety, I found Tamil Nadu much concerned about education of female and cleanliness of the city as well.

Why is the south Indian temple structure different from the ones in North India?

The first obvious difference you would see between North and South Indian temples is the sheer size. Southern temples are much larger in comparision. It is fair to say that, South Indian kings invested a lot in temples than their palaces, which is quite the opposite in the North. Srirangam Ranganathar temple in Tamilnadu occupies an area of 156 acres, making it the largest working worship place in the world. In perspective, the entire area of the country of Monaco (2 sq. km) can only hold three Srirangam temples. Vatican City can only hold 2/3rd of Srirangam temple. None of the North Indian te

The first obvious difference you would see between North and South Indian temples is the sheer size. Southern temples are much larger in comparision. It is fair to say that, South Indian kings invested a lot in temples than their palaces, which is quite the opposite in the North. Srirangam Ranganathar temple in Tamilnadu occupies an area of 156 acres, making it the largest working worship place in the world. In perspective, the entire area of the country of Monaco (2 sq. km) can only hold three Srirangam temples. Vatican City can only hold 2/3rd of Srirangam temple. None of the North Indian temples are as grand as these structures.

Srirangam Raja Gopuram of height 239 ft is the tallest temple tower in the world.

What are the differences between North Indian and South Indian Hindu temples?

God is one.

Born and lived my life in Delhi but last 10 years in Hyd, I feel little privileged to answer this.

Dressing- In North ,in many Temples, I have seen women in jeans ( I am writing about metros in North) but in South, ladies prefer suits and sarees. However, ladies look beautiful in anything..) In some Temples in South, men have to wear dhoti, it's a mandate, have seen this less in north.

Pooja Vidhi or rituals- In North, Abhishek of God doesn't happen that much, in South that happens.

Preference-In South, married women prefer wearing mangalsutr or sacred thread along with toering. In North, sindhoor or Vermillion is enough in some places of worship.

In South, people take round of God and in north, it's less to be seen.

Pay and Darshan- I have seen it more in South like darshan ticket, However I have seen it less in north, though it's catching up.

One thing I like in South Indian Temple is it's very process oriented, you can only do things, one after another and in no hurry.

Common thing in both the temples is that people are ready to help you with there rituals to perform the pooja and it still imbibes the feeling that God is one !

Why are South Indian temples bigger and grander than North Indian temples?

No South India doesnt have more temples because South Indians were Temple builders while North wasnt.

Its only because almost all temples of North India were destroyed by Jih@di barbarian invaders and number of temples standing is indirectly proportional to barbarism of jih@di invasion.

North India acted as shield taking all the blows for 1000s of years while South was relatively protected still some vermins like Malik Kafur, nizams, Tipu, Bahmani Sultans slipped through and destroyed Vijayanagara temples, Attacked Madurai Meenakshi temple, Tipu destroyed 8000 temples.

If one can time travel and go to 711 AD before first barbarian Bin Qasim broke through Indian defences due to our stupid secularism and betrayal of fes, the density of temples from Sindh to Kanyakumari would have been the same and even the grandeur.

The Sun Temple of Multan was supposed to be the most glorious temple of India.

Kashmiri temples were architectural wonders.

So rather than being haughty that south Kings made better temples while Northern Indians were savages, its better to thank their sacrifices as they fought with everything and managed to save dharma and memories of some glorious temples.

Somnath was destroyed but memory was preserved, Mathura was ransacked, Varanasi was ransacked, Nalanda was ransacked, Konark was attacked, Jagannath Puri was attacked, Ayodhya temple was destroyed, all Maharashtra temples were attacked and destroyed by Aurangzeb, Afzal Khan and gang, Prayagraj temples were ransacked and if you count it will be in thousands.

If one has to see sheer density of glorious temples, one has to go to Bagan in Burma and other parts where Indic civilisation made thousands of temples following Indian architecture schools which included architects from North India, south India, east India. Indians stopping jih@dis was reason South East Asia had their temples intact and only nature has made changes to them and made them appear more ethereal.

We need to be as proud of Rajaraja Chola, Krishnadeva Raya as of Rana Kumbha, Bappa Rawal, Lalitaditya muktapida, Suheldev, Ahilyabai Holkar and hundreds of other warriors who ensured that our Dharma survives intact even if our temples were destroyed.

Temples can be remade as they are rightfully being done if soul of our Bharat is kept Intact.

There are many differences between North Indian and South Indian Hindu temples, including their architecture, rituals, and deities worshipped. Here are a few examples:

  1. Architecture: One of the most noticeable differences between North Indian and South Indian temples is their architecture. North Indian temples tend to have a more ornate and elaborate style, with tall spires and intricate carvings, while South Indian temples tend to have a simpler and more functional design, with a focus on large open spaces.
  2. Rituals: The rituals and ceremonies performed in North Indian and South Indian temples ca

There are many differences between North Indian and South Indian Hindu temples, including their architecture, rituals, and deities worshipped. Here are a few examples:

  1. Architecture: One of the most noticeable differences between North Indian and South Indian temples is their architecture. North Indian temples tend to have a more ornate and elaborate style, with tall spires and intricate carvings, while South Indian temples tend to have a simpler and more functional design, with a focus on large open spaces.
  2. Rituals: The rituals and ceremonies performed in North Indian and South Indian temples can also vary significantly. For example, in North Indian temples, puja (worship) is typically performed by a priest, while in South Indian temples, it is more common for worshippers to participate in the rituals themselves.
  3. Deities worshipped: The deities worshipped in North Indian and South Indian temples can also differ. In North Indian temples, it is common to find images of gods and goddesses from the Vedas, such as Lord Vishnu and Lord Shiva, while in South Indian temples, the focus is often on local deities and village gods.

It is worth noting that these are just a few examples of the differences between North Indian and South Indian temples, and there is a great deal of diversity within each region as well. There are many factors that contribute to the differences between temples, including regional customs, cultural traditions, and historical influences.

It looks devastated because it is devastated. Many of the temples and other structures in North India were destroyed during the Islamic invasions and the subsequent Mughal rule. Why are Hindu idols in North Indian temples different from South Indian temples?

Hindu Idols in temples were created with philosophical meaning, religious inspiration and reflect different aspects of the local culture, folk and thoughts on divinity. Therefore, Idols served as the vehicle or channel for devotees visiting the temple and was not just a mere piece of art. In the Shilpa shastras details such as the length and circumference of fingers, length of nails, length of nose, etc. are dealt with in detail. Guidelines concerning the eyes, lips, hand positions, clothes, ornaments are also given. No two images are the same. Body anatomy, stances, vehicles, headgear etc. ar

Hindu Idols in temples were created with philosophical meaning, religious inspiration and reflect different aspects of the local culture, folk and thoughts on divinity. Therefore, Idols served as the vehicle or channel for devotees visiting the temple and was not just a mere piece of art. In the Shilpa shastras details such as the length and circumference of fingers, length of nails, length of nose, etc. are dealt with in detail. Guidelines concerning the eyes, lips, hand positions, clothes, ornaments are also given. No two images are the same. Body anatomy, stances, vehicles, headgear etc. are all different.

Why the difference ?

Various materials can be used to make the Idol. The location of the shrine, climate and uses are all taken into consideration when deciding the material. The details mentioned in scriptures also taken into account.

Difference based on material :

In the ancient Vedic text, Bhavisyapurana, seven main types of materials from which Idols can be used are mentioned: stone, metals such as gold, silver and copper; wood, earth or clay, sand, paint, and gems.

  • Clay Idols : In ancient India, clay Idols had been popular especially so in north India. This is explained by the easily available clays and muds deposited by the north's many rivers. In addition, clay is easily worked upon by even the lesser talented of Idol makers.
  • Wooden Idols :Wooden Idols are carved. However, due to their fragile nature they are not very popular. The Jagannath mandir in Jagannathpuri to this day replaces its wooden images of Krishna, Balarama and Subhadra every 12 or 19 years.
  • Bronze Idols :From the late 9th century to the late 13th century the Chola dynasty ruled much of south India. Chola art is best-known for its temple bronze sculpture of Hindu gods and goddesses, many of which were designed to be carried in local processions during temple festivals.
  • Marble Idols : Most of the temples in North India have lot of carved marble idols including Buddhist and Jain temples. The marble derived from limestone were available in great quantity in Rajasthan. The ability of marble allowing light to pass diffusely gives a realistic appearance to the idols. Also marbles are weather resistant.

In Southern India, the material used predominantly for idols is black stone, while material in North India is white marble due to the availability of the material.

Difference based on appearance :

The gods and goddess were seen in two forms :

  • Raudra or Ugra - are images that were meant to terrify, induce fear. These typically have wide, circular eyes, carry weapons, have skulls and bones as adornment. These idols were worshipped by soldiers before going to war, or by people in times of distress or errors. North India have many temples of deties like Shiva, Durga, Kali.
  • Shanta and Saumya - are images that were pacific, peaceful and expressive of love, compassion, kindness and other virtues in Hindu pantheon. These images would carry symbolic icons of peace, knowledge, music, wealth, flowers. South India temple gods like Guruvayoor krishna, Tirupati Balaji.

Certainly not all idols depict the same god nor does it depict every god in the same way. In fact, the same deity can have more than one murti that reflects different aspects, features, and roles of it. For example, the god Shiva is depicted in his daksinamurti form as a teacher in South India; but in North India, he is standing as Pasupati protecting animals and humans. The different forms depict the religious beliefs and cultural history of the place.

Despite the differences the idols served as a focus for worship, a portal for the experience of god. The different forms, looks of the idols helped the devotee to achieve a personal experience of their god.

South Indian temple architecture, also called Drvia Style, architecture invariably employed for Hindu temples in modern Tamil Nadu from the 7th to the 18th century, characterized by its pyramidal, or kina-type, tower. Variant forms are found in Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh states. The South Indian temple consists essentially of a square-chambered sanctuary topped by a superstructure, tower, or spire and an attached pillared porch or hall ,enclosed by a peristyle of cells within a rectangular court. The external walls of the temple are segmented by pilasters and carry niches housing sculpture. The superstructure or tower above the sanctuary is of the kina type and consists of an arrangement of gradually receding stories in a pyramidal shape.The tower is topped by a dome-shaped cupola and a crowning pot and finial.

The origins of the Drvia style can be observed in the Gupta period. The earliest extant examples of the developed style are the 7th-century rock-cut shrines at Mahbalipuram and a developed structural temple, the Shore Temple (c. 700), at the same site.

The South Indian style is most fully realized in the splendid Bhadvara temple at Thanjvr, built about 100310 by Rjarja the Great, and the great temple at Gagaikoacapuram, built about 1025 by his son Rjendra Cla. Subsequently, the style became increasingly elaboratethe complex of temple buildings enclosed by the court became larger, and a number of successive enclosures, each with its own gateway (gopura), were added. By the Vijayanagar period (13361565) the gopuras had increased in size so that they dominated the much smaller temples inside the enclosures.

North Indian temple architecture also calledThe Nagara style which developed for the fifth century is characterized by a beehive shaped tower (called a shikhara, in northern terminology) made up of layer upon layer of architectural elements such as kapotas and gavaksas, all topped by a large round cushion-like element called an amalaka. The plan is based on a square but the walls are sometimes so broken up that the tower often gives the impression of being circular. Moreover, in later developments such as in the Chandella temples, the central shaft was surrounded by many smaller reproductions of itself, creating a spectacular visual effect resembling a fountain.

Originally Answered: What is the difference between North and South Indian temples?

One of the difference is the access of the sanctum (the place where the idols or the deity resides) - "Garbha griha" in Sanskrit.
North Indian temples will allow access to "Garbha Griha" or the sanctum as the approach to reach God is said to be "Bhakthi Marga" (not a correct translation, Reach God through Devotion) whereas South Indian temples will not allow access to "Garbha Griha" or the sanctum (moreover the sanctum will be right in the centre of the temple and poorly illuminated, reason - the concentration power will be more in dimly lit rooms) as the approach to reach God is said to be "Jnana Marga" (for people who cannot pronounce "Jnana" - North Indians - read Jnana as Gyan, - some of South Indians - read as Gnana) i.e. Reach God through knowledge.

How different are Maharashtrians from North Indians and South Indians?

I am a Tamilian who lived in Pune for thirty years. So, I think I can answer this for the south Indian part.

Maharashtrians are more proud of their language and they use Marathi as much as possible in every forum. You may think Tamilians are proud of their mother tongue. I am a Tamilian who lived in Pune for thirty years. So, I think I can answer this for the south Indian part.

Maharashtrians are more proud of their language and they use Marathi as much as possible in every forum. You may think Tamilians are proud of their mother tongue. They may talk vociferously but turn to English next moment. In our company, even company notice boards were full of Marathi. For example, I am a member of two what's app groups. My Pune housing society has all posts in Marathi though we have doctors and engineers and my Tiruchi housing society posts are all in English.

Maharashtrians follow method of group worship. The sarvajanik Ganeshotsav is an example. Even in offices during any puja, all would start in unison sukha kharta dukkha hartha vartha vignachi, ( hats off to Swami Samatha Ramdas and his organisational skills) and I had to at least keep the beat by clapping my hands though I could not sing like them. Tamilians are individual worshippers. They call others during Puja but only for giving Prasad.

Maharashtrians are great dramatists. The one act plays in Balgandharva used to be attended by all and drama actors are more popular than film artistes. South Indians have relegated stage to TV and cinema. Incidentally, I have not seen big hoardings for film artistes and people pouring milk on their posters in Maharashtra which are acceptable practices at least in Tamilnadu.

Maharashtrians display a surprising familiarity with Sanskrit and the Hindu scriptures. An Electrician by name Uday Khose used to come to my house and once after completing his work casually told me that he needed to hurry up as he was to deliver a lecture on Gnaneswari ( Marathi version of Bhagavad Gita) in the local temple. I was dumb founded.

South Indians are generally not bothered about their names. Tamilians, in fact, do not have any surname or caste name. Maharashtrians would first check your name ( surname or aadnav) before getting close with you. Many could not solve the puzzle about my origin as chandrasekaran could be from any caste. This makes them appear insular.

Tamilians at least are very emotional. They use their brains only for some time and their hearts most of the time. If some one cries and asks for votes they may vote forgetting whatever he did. Maharashtrians are more logical. They know the path to power is by bargaining and they would leverage their position to gain strength. I cannot help remembering how Ekoji took over Tanjore without a fight.

Maharashtrians go abroad and many return to start some business. South Indians go abroad and become citizens of that country. With the result, in Tamilnadu, grand mothers know more about weather in Washington than whether it rains in Kolkata.

Maharashtrians celbrate their King Chathrapathi Shivaji so much that an alien like me can get bored. South Indians are shy of celebrating their Kings. Tamilians could even talk ill of Raja Raja Chola who was the greatest of Tamil Kings and get away with it but I cannot imagine what would happen to a person if he or she talks ill of Shivaji.

Tamilians show their anger very quickly. They get angry at almost everything. In traffic signals and restaurants, you can see some angry person almost everyday. But the anger evaporates and they are back to normal very soon. On the contrary, Maharashtrians do not show their anger. They swallow their anger and take revenge at the next opportunity.

Disclaimer: Though I have lived in Maharashtra for thirty years, I have lived in Pune only and it is quite possible that some statements do not reflect the situation in say Beed or Chiplun.

Why are there such few temples in North India compared to the South India?

North India has been under muslim rulers for longer than South India, hence they have suffered greater destruction of culture and architecture than South India. Muslim rulers believed that destroying Hindu temples & monasteries, converting / killing the priests and building mosques on top of temples would guarantee them access to heaven. We can see the result of that all over India - especially North India. Go to any major monument - eg Kutub Minar - and you will see temple pillars stacked on top of each other to create mosques.

As a result of an orgy of iconoclasm, there are very few ancient

North India has been under muslim rulers for longer than South India, hence they have suffered greater destruction of culture and architecture than South India. Muslim rulers believed that destroying Hindu temples & monasteries, converting / killing the priests and building mosques on top of temples would guarantee them access to heaven. We can see the result of that all over India - especially North India. Go to any major monument - eg Kutub Minar - and you will see temple pillars stacked on top of each other to create mosques.

As a result of an orgy of iconoclasm, there are very few ancient Hindu temples in North India. Those that survived are in remote places, or kingdoms survived the islamic rule of north india and where Hindu rulers managed to protect their lands.

Every major pilgrimage centre in North India has a massive Mughal era mosque, created by one of the Mughal emperors. Aurangzeb was one of the most notorious for destroying temples and taking over their lands for his own enrichment. Mathura and Kashi are the most obvious examples of this. Mosques mushroomed on top of ruins of Hindu temples. You can see many unused mosques and overcrowded temples.

Until the fall of the mughal empire, Hindus across North India were not allowed to build temples or renovate broken ones. So you will find the temples across north India usually date from 1750s onwards. Truly old ones are rare to find. One of the Hindu sects, Pushti Marg, even changed its architectural style and called their temples haveli - mansions - to avoid government ire. No more spires, no more sculptures on the walls and pillars. Just a discrete, windowless tall wall to protect a complex layout of courtyards and halls inside. This would confuse the attacker and give them time to hide the main murti in case of emergency. Hindu temples became smaller, discrete to avoid the attention of muslim rulers. Size of Hindu deities also decreased and became smaller, lighter, to make it easy for priests to hide their deities in case of an attack.

All Hindu cultural activities associated with temples - dance, music, singing, paintings, sculptures - all these died out in North India. Thats where there are no Hindu dance traditions left in North India. Manipuri, Oddisi, Bharta Natyam, Kuchupudi, Kathakali - all exist on the periphery of the muslim kingdoms of North India. Even Hindu musical traditions existed only outside islamic rule.

After the muslim and christian rule ended, a resurgence in temple building took place all over India. Temples, commisioned by rich individuals and prosperous communities flourished across the north. But due to the fact that they did not have royal grant of land or resources, these temples were by necessity small in size and ambition.

South India staved off the muslim rule for longer and managed to keep their temples and their wealth for longer period. They too suffered, but not for as long as the north. Temples destroyed by raids of muslim hoards were rebuilt and repaired. By being protected by Hoysala, Vijayanagar, Maratha and Maysor empires, they managed to preserve their culture all the way to modern times.

Now there is a new temple being constructed at Mayapur Bengal , which has brought in elements of western classical architecture with middle age Indian architecture .When I say middle age architecture it has elements of Buddhism as well . Look at the picture below.

If you look at this temple ,this is a combination of Indian architecture with Greeco-Roman architecture. Now there is another temple being developed at Vrindavan which has combined the Nagara architecture with Modern Neo-Futuristic architecture.

Look here .This is essentially a skyscraper made of nagara architecture fused with neo-futurist architecture.

Now why did I showed these examples ? It is because I wanted to show the impact of other cultures on the Hindu culture . The pure hindu architecture is fused with other cultures as different cultures entered north India , Islam , Bactrians and the British. While some of the rule was extremist and horrible , architecture always evolves and this is how they evolved. There is also a resurge of pure vedic architecture , Neo-Vedic in the temples and it can be found in the Akshardham style .

  • The north Indian temple architecture is known as NAGARA style while south one is DRAVIDA style.

Originally Answered: What is the difference between North and South Indian temples?

Age
South India has temples that have survived for about 1000 years where as many of ancient ones in North have been destroyed by invading armies and Islamic empires.

Architecture
South Indian temples of Tamilnadu, Karnataka and Andhra follow the Dravidian architecture, characterized by successive tall gopurams (gates) leading to the main garbhagriha. The vimana over the garbhagriha is not usually quite tall (there are exceptions like Brihadeshwara temple).

In north indian temples the vimana is taller than other structures.

Kerala and coastal Karnataka temples are follow a different architecture scheme - usually without vimanas (of course with exceptions - for example, Thiruvananthapuram Ananatha Padmanabhaswamy temple).

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindu_temple#Regional_variations_in_Hindu_temples

Access to Public
A major difference between NI and SI temples is the access of the murthis to the public. NI temples typically allow unrestricted access to public to touch and do pujas by themselves. However entry and access to the garbhagraha is restricted to public and only the priests have access to the murthis to do pujas.

Is the Hinduism of South India and North India the same?

Yes. Hinduism of South and North are same. Let us see what other religions require by way of practice to call it a religion.

Quran is read in mosque while Bible passages are recited in churches. In North I see bhajans - similar to South people chant different types of shlok, veda, stotra, vernacular language carnatic music

PS: Many comments are made that just like Gita, even Quran and Bible do not SAY about conversion but it is followers who fake the conversion aspect (on which all holy books are silent).

Yes. Hinduism of South and North are same. Let us see what other religions require by way of practice to call it a religion.

Scripture

Quran is read in mosque while Bible passages are recited in churches. In North I see bhajans - similar to South people chant different types of shlok, veda, stotra, vernacular language carnatic music

PS: Many comments are made that just like Gita, even Quran and Bible do not SAY about conversion but it is followers who fake the conversion aspect (on which all holy books are silent).

Pandit/Preacher

Mullah of Sunni or Imam of Shia oversee marriage, other rituals. Clergy does the baptism, marriage etc., in churcheschurches. In North, there is a ghodi (horse) for the groom, while in South there is no horses but bollywood films shows cars. While forward castes perform rites before fire in both North and South, backward classes pour milk to consummate Hindu marriages. A pandit in North can be from any caste, as long as he chants some mantra similar to South Indian functions inviting certain temple priests to officiate.

Wearing of dresses:

A mullah/imam/clergy wear a specific gown to officiate. Both North & South Indian Hindus normally do not wear special gown/cloth in traditional pooja or worship. In fact people cannot even differentiate a Pandit from other normal folk/hosts/guests.

Idol worship

Shia muslims use a hand symbol in their Imam baras denoting the 5 fingers to be Mohammed the prophet, his daughter, son-in-law, 2 grand sons, while Sunni muslims in India face towards the western side in mosques (since Meccah is to the west of India). Christians have symbolisms in churches like the jesus on a cross, mother mary holding baby jesus etc. All these superstitions are nothing short of idol worship. Similarly both north & South Indian Hindus personally perform pooja to idols. if a pooja is performed in office in south India, Hindus of both South & North India all perform Harathi even if there is a pandit present.

Originally Answered: What is the difference between North and South Indian temples?

South Indian Temples vs North Indian Temples

South Indian temples and North Indian temples differ between them in terms of their construction, practice and the like.

Rituals:-
The rituals performed in the North Indian temples are very simple when compared to the rituals performed in the South Indian temples. The South Indian temples are used to elaborate methods of rituals.
Sanskrit Agama scriptural traditions are strictly adhered to in the performance of rituals in the South Indian temples.

The North Indian temples are less orthodox when compared to the South Indian temples, in

South Indian Temples vs North Indian Temples

South Indian temples and North Indian temples differ between them in terms of their construction, practice and the like.

Rituals:-
The rituals performed in the North Indian temples are very simple when compared to the rituals performed in the South Indian temples. The South Indian temples are used to elaborate methods of rituals.
Sanskrit Agama scriptural traditions are strictly adhered to in the performance of rituals in the South Indian temples.

Practices:-
The North Indian temples are less orthodox when compared to the South Indian temples, in the sense, that every body is permitted to enter the innermost sanctum of the deity in most of the North Indian temples, whereas, the South Indian temples prescribe certain rules and regulations regarding the entry into the main and the principal sanctum of the deity. Temples in Kerala prescribe many orthodox rules while entering into them. Men should enter most of the temples only with a bare chest. They are not supposed to wear the upper garment while entering into the temples.
In the North Indian temples the principal deity is not decorated with precious jewelry, since everybody is allowed to enter into the principal sanctum of the deity.

Architecture:-
Most of the North Indian temples do not contain surrounding corridors and halls, while many South Indian temples like the Meenakshi Amman Temple in Madurai contain surrounding corridors and halls.
In North Indian temples you can find that the tallest towers are constructed over the sanctum sanctorum. This is not the case with many of the South Indian temples.
Many South Indian temples have processional deities too made of panchaloha an alloy of five metals in additional to the principal deity. These processional deities are not seen in the North Indian temples.

Source - Difference Between South Indian Temples and North Indian Temples

Vijaya Lakshmi

Do South Indians like North Indian dishes?

I am a South Indian and like many North Indian dishes.

But unfortunately I have not tasted all the dishes. We were in Nagpur for 17 years. So tasted many Western and central India dishes.

We were in Bhubaneswar for 15 years. I have tasted many Eastern India dishes.

I am born and brought up in South India so I tasted almost all of them.

But we had been to North India occasionally on some holiday trips and stayed only for few days. So though I tasted some of them I might have missed good delicacies of North.

These are the items I love:

1. Stuffed Parathas and Kulchas: I make stuffed parathas occasionally. I have tried(made) Kulchas many years back.

2. Tandoori Roti: I never tried making it at home. But we would very often go to an authentic dabha when we were in Nagpur to have them.

3.Butter paneer masala/Paneer butter masala: Kids loved it as an accompaniment for tandoori roti. I have tried a few times at home but could not achieve that taste.

4. Palak paneer: I make it often in my home and it is always a hit.

5. Navratan kurma: I made it very often when the children were still kids. But dabha taste is better.

6. Malpua: One of our family friends in Nagpur made it in excellent way.

7. Gajar ka Halva: I make it frequently. But it was an utter flop when I have first tried it after my marriage. You may read Vijaya Lakshmi's answer to Have you ever tried to cook something that ended up a disaster?, if are interested.

8. Mothi choor ke laddu: I think it originated in North India. I never saw anybody making at home. We always purchase at sweet shops.

9. Kulfi: Whenever we went to a dabha it was a mandatory dessert for all of us.

10. Agra Petha: The aroma, the texture and cool look always bring back my childhood memories whenever I see this food item. Some of our close relatives have adopted Radha Soami religion. They would often go to Dayalbagh and while returning, bring this item for us. I love this sweet.

11. Chole Bhture:

12. Rajma: In north India people eat it with rice. But at our home we eat it with roti.

I will add when I remember more.

How is North and South defined in geographic terms

  • Architectural - there are many different styles - Dravida, Utkala, Hemadpant, Nagari and so on. One could say Nagari is predominant in the North, while Dravida in South.

  • Then Sampradaya - South typically are more Agamic - Shaiva/Vaishnava/Saktha - like Pancharatra or Vaikanasa. North seems more syncretic, so not that traditional or organized. More open to access.

What are some good things about people of Tamil Nadu?

There are lot of good things about tamil people which has come along with the culture that they have been following for centuries . Here are few

(1) Hospitality (called as virunthomal in tamil)

Tamilians treat their guests equal to God. It is still a culture to look after guests with extreme sweetness that it has got deeply ingrained in their blood. Greeting guests with absolute hospitality is seen as a great mannerism all around tamilnadu!

There is a famous Thirukural (poetic couplets written by famous tamil poet thiruvalluvar) which goes as follows


There are lot of good things about tamil people which has come along with the culture that they have been following for centuries . Here are few

(1) Hospitality (called as virunthomal in tamil)

Tamilians treat their guests equal to God. It is still a culture to look after guests with extreme sweetness that it has got deeply ingrained in their blood. Greeting guests with absolute hospitality is seen as a great mannerism all around tamilnadu!

There is a famous Thirukural (poetic couplets written by famous tamil poet thiruvalluvar) which goes as follows


(Though food of immortality should crown the board,
Feasting alone, the guests without unfed, is thing abhorred) This one couplet is enough to sum up how tamil people look after their guests. It is written in ancient scriptures that there used to be a culture then to cook extra for a person or two in a home so that there will be enough food to feed even strange passersby who happened to take meals in strangers home in those days. The trace of this culture is still prevalent in lot of tamil families.

To aid the tired travellers.. in almost all homes in those days(even in few homes of certain towns in these days) they had thinnai (a raised platform in the front of the house). These thinnais were used to take rest by those tired passersby. Glimpse of those is as follows

(2) Linguistic patriotism (tamil patru)

Tamil people are great patriots of their mother tongue tamil. Patriot enough that they worship their language in the form of a motherly goddess called as Tamilannai

Even today after alot of advancements, the first thing that a child ever gets taught at home is to write the first tamil letter

As it is widely known tamil language is one of the oldest languages in the history of languages.. The part of the credit to this leagacy goes to the tamil people who have strived hard to keep this alive in all these years through their patriotism!

(3)Cultural patriotism(kalachaara patru)

Though modern times have taken away a lot of our long followed cultures, tamil people have still kept a lot of their culture and tradition alive! To mention just one

Jallikattu-This one word may sound like a great goosebump for almost all tamilans.This word jallikattu denotes a traditional tamil sport which is specially played by men where in which a fully grown bull is tried to calm from its beaming aggression. The exact tamil word for it is Yeruthaluvuthal which means hugging a bull while trying to calm it.

The game looks much like this

Last year by the month of January a hell big protest happened here in tamilnadu to lift the ban of this sport being imposed by the supreme court. The protest drew a national attention in which all the myths behind this sport were made open to the world and the truth got staged. It is a highly animal friendly sport-it took a whole lot of 6 Cr peoples protest to nail this one truth. Tamil people hardly let go of their traditional values. Domestic animals like bulls tamed in this sport are treated more like a family member by the breeders that even little kid isnt afraid to be with it like this

Tamil people value their traditions highly!!!!!!!!

(4) Most welcoming state(Vandhaarai vaazha vaikum tamilagam)

Tamil people being highly known for their hospitality are also equally welcoming ones. They are very tolerant and accepting towards people from other different parts. Chennai the state capital is a metro with a lot of job opportunities where we can find a lot of other state people too! Tamilians do live in total harmony with everyone there and even treat them more like one among them. Dissolving in the difference is a rare yet one of the most sweet manners one can possess and tamil people do have that rightfully!

We accept people from any race, culture and language orientation as one among us! We have loved and celebrated a lot of cinema stars, admistrative leaders, artists, singers, business tycoons etc who had different origins!

These are few of the fine qualities that tamil people do own :) :) Feeling proud and happy to share this!

The cuisine of Odisha is simple, economic yet temptingly delicious. The food is spicy, hot and thereby foodies having savory mouth will certainly enjoy the food items that Odisha offers.However what makes Odia dishes different from others is the use of a variety of spices and the way they use it.

1. Cooking procedures are simple and this lets the dishes retain their nourishment.

2. Besides spicy and tasty, Odia delicacies are less caloric value as they are cooked with little or no oil. Curd and coconut are used mainly in the preparations that give extra zing.

3. A meal is not served by courses. Usually, all dishes are served together and then only eating starts. The main dish is served in a thali, a large plate and other dishes are served in small bowls and plates. On festive occasions, the banana leaf is used instead of thali.

(Odia Thali)

4. Owing to its vast coastline, large number of people relish fish and seafoods delicacies. Dishes made of prawn, fishes, crabs are most popular and mouth watering.

(Machha Besara)

(Kankada Masala)

6. Mahaprasad is the food of Lord Jagannath and is available at the Anand Bazar of the Jagannath temple. Its massive cooking that takes place in the temple kitchen which is one of the biggest kitchens in the world is the specialty of this sacred food.The Jagannath Temple at Puri, Odisha feeds 100,000 people on a festival day and for about 25,000 on a normal day. It is believed that Goddess Mahalaxmi cooks in the Kitchen Herself; and all the cooks are her servants. It is also said that if Mother Laxmi is displeased with the preparations by the cooks, a dog will appear mysteriously on the temple grounds. If the dog is seen, all the food must be buried and prepared again.

(Shri Jagannatha Mahaprasada)

Fifty-six verieties of food is made everyday at Shri Jagannath Dham for Prasad known as Chhapan Bhog.

One more interesting thing about Mahaprasad is there is no use of potato in any food item even if it is an important ingredient of Odia foods and other Indian foods also.

7. Pakhala

Pakhaa is an Odia term for an Indian food consisting of cooked rice washed or little fermented in water. The liquid part is known as Torai. In Sanskrit this food is called Parjyusitannam.

This is the favourite food of every Odia people. When you add some Ginger, Chilly, Lemon, Coriander leaves and Curry leaves to it, it becomes more tasty.

You can also ad some Curd to it so that it becomes more tasty and looks like this:

(Dahi Pakhala)

I have a lot of Non-Odia friends in college (Specially Bihari and Jharkhandi) who die for this in Summer. ( our College Canteen provides Pakhala as an optional food in Summer). whenever I go home I eat pakhala, only once of twice, though I love it because it has very rich content of Carbohydrates. But those who have never tried it must try it once.

We, Odia people can proudly say that "It stays in our soul". If you want to know about Odisha and Odia people you can't exclude this food. It is a great relief for every Odia specially in Summer. There is a song "Mo Odisha" most Odias have seen on TV which has a line "Odia mana, Odia prana bujhe pakhara kansa..." which describes our love for Pakhala.

Some people believe that Odia people are lazy compared to some other Indian people. Well this is the primary cause of that lazyness :P . Only Odias can understand this.

March 20 is celebrated as Pakhala Diwas by Odias worldwide.

8. dalma

Dalma is a food item made with Dal and some vegetables. This is an unique Odia food with great taste.

9. Pitha

We eat a wide verieties of Pitha ( Can be called as Indian version of cake).

We also make certain Pithas for certain occasions specially. Like Enduri pitha is a must for Prathamastami Puja, Manda pitha is a must for Manabasa Gurubara. Chitau pitha is made on Chitalagi Amabasya.

10. Last but not the least, Bela pana

Bela pana is a drink made from bael fruit pulp, in the month of Chaitra and Boishakh, in Odisha.

Odias celebrate their new year on The Maha Bisuba Sankranti which is similar to the New Year festivals observed elsewhere in India, such as Vaisakhi (Punjab region), Bihu(Assam), Maithili New Year, Naba Barsha or Pohela Boishakh (Bengal), Bisu Parba (Tulu Nadu), Vishu (Kerala) and Puthandu (Tamil Nadu).

The use of Bela pana on this day is so popular among Odias that we also named this new year day as Pana Sankranti.

Why didn't North Indians build large temples in ancient times like South India?

Large temple construction started much earlier in the north, by the time of Guptas,at least 3 to 6 centuries earlier compared to the south.

The main problem with north india was the use of less stable material like wood and bricks, Less stable foundations, and widespread destruction and reuse by the marauding Islamic militias and locals.

Why aren't there 1,000-year-old temples in North India like South India?

There is only one reason - North India was ruled for over 600 years by rulers belonging to an iconoclastic faith which abhorred idol worship and polytheism. It was considered an act of great religious merit if such places of worship were destroyed. As a result, very few temples in North India from the pre Islamic era are still standing.

The best example of iconoclasm is the mosque near Qutub Minar in the national capital. One can see a mosque called Masjid Quwwat ul Islam (might of Islam). It was the first mosque built by the Delhi Sultanate after it was established in 1192 CE. It was built after partially demolishing a temple complex that stood there. It is evident that the mosque was originally a temple to ...

What's the difference between North Indian temples and South Indian temples?

Perhaps it was the Vindhyas or the Deccan ranges, but southern India was not conquered and durably subdued for centuries by hordes from the west. either colonial or by mid-eastern powers, that resulted in wanton destruction of a great many Northern temples. So it is instructive to compare the scale, size, grandeur, workmanship and sheer elegance of the many many stone structures all over South India as epitomized by Meenakshi Amman koyil in Madurai or Tirunelveli Kovil, or Virupaksha, Brigadeeshwara or Suchindram or the hundreds of smaller but exquisitely carved temple complexes. Perhaps it was the Vindhyas or the Deccan ranges, but southern India was not conquered and durably subdued for centuries by hordes from the west. either colonial or by mid-eastern powers, that resulted in wanton destruction of a great many Northern temples. So it is instructive to compare the scale, size, grandeur, workmanship and sheer elegance of the many many stone structures all over South India as epitomized by Meenakshi Amman koyil in Madurai or Tirunelveli Kovil, or Virupaksha, Brigadeeshwara or Suchindram or the hundreds of smaller but exquisitely carved temple complexes. Humongous never-ending structures of devotion and sincere workmanship to glorify Him, with small sanctum-sanctorums. What are some of the major cultural differences between Northern and Southern India?

Such questions would require some generalizations and understanding that there is no "all", "every" in this answer. [To get a scale of the size, the distance between India's northernmost state and the southernmost is more than the distance between France and Nigeria or from Canada to central Mexico or from Ukraine to Saudi Arabia]

For the purposes of this answer, I will take "north India" as those part of present India that were a part of the Gupta empire. It is a more cohesive group .

Land locked vs long coastlines

Most of north India is land locked while south India is characterized by long coastlines. This has an impact in lot of the culture. Thus, on an average south Indians are little bit more prosperous and more trade links. South Indians also tend to migrate a lot. Thus, although south India forms less than a fifth of the Indian population, almost half of Indians you see outside India are likely to come from the south. [One exception is Gujarat, which despite being in north has a long coastline and thus have all the same properties above - more trade and migration]

Water, History and Civilizations

North India is a colossal alluvial plain stretching from the river Indus in Punjab all the way to river Brahmaputra flowing through the plains of Assam. It is fed by 4 of the glorious perennial rivers of the subcontinent - Indus, Ganga, Yamuna and Brahmaputra. With the present evidence, the Indian civilization is believed to have originated in these alluvial plains producing some of the glorious empires, universities and architecture that outsiders often associate with India.

The south has a variety of great rivers too such as the Godhavari, Krishna and Cauvery, but these are not glacier fed rivers and thus the flow varies a lot between the rainy season and the dry season. It is believed that the main civilization started a little after those of the Indus and even moved from there. These two civilizations are sometimes called the Aryan [north] and Dravidian [south] civilizations, although it is debatable how distinct these differences are.

While the south probably urbanized later than the north, south got a slight upperhand in urbanization in the colonial era as the north was deurbanized in the centuries of invasions prior. South India was among the first regions in India to be colonized by the English, going as early as 1600s. North India was colonized nearly two centuries later. Under the colonial rule, south India developed more urban centers and also adopted more English. Until the 1911 movement of national capital to Delhi, north India was blighted in urban development with no major metropolis.

Impact of invasions and wars

Most of the wars and invasions involving India was fought at the north. The only real entry point into the subcontinent lies in the extreme north - in a mountain pass in Afghanistan. The pass is extremely far from the south. Thus, South India has never really had invasions or major wars with outsiders. The one exception to that is the European occupation, which was through the sea. However even that was far more smooth in the south than in the north.


Thus, the south was able to protect its ancient artifacts and culture better than in the north, where invasions often resulted in the destruction of precious temples and art works. South is thus less on the edge when it comes to the foreign influence, while the north can often be on the boil and sometimes even resulting in riots. South Indians are less concerned about "protecting culture" through political means and more nonchalant in this subject. This reflects a lot in the southern voting patterns vs northern voting patterns.

Nation and identity

India is far more of a cultural union than a political union. Unlike in the other civilizations the historical kings neither claimed divine origins nor wrote elaborate constitutions. All of the social control was left to the cultural controls [the collection of which is presently tagged as Hinduism]. The vestiges of these social control [such as the caste system] can be seen even today. Thus, while India has been a nation for all of its history, it was not always a single state.

North India often was under a single political union, while the south has had totally different political empires and multiple of them. Thus, the northerners historically tend to emphasize more on "national identity" and "integrating India" often worried that the union would break up. The south was more on the cultural sphere often pushes back on forced political integration. Given that the south has seldom had invasions and more confident of culture, its point of view is that such political controls are superfluous and harmful. Thus, the southern view and northern view of what India is can often be quite different.

Also, while the north is a more cohesive group, the southern states are far more distinct from each other. Thus, south India is not one political or even a cultural entity, while it could be argued that north India is more closer to one. Thus, south Indians tend to see things more from their own state prisms than anything like "south India".

Language and identity

North Indians tend to speak Indo-European languages usually attributed to Sanskrit origins. While the southern languages [termed the Dravidian family] also have a lot of Sanskrit vocabulary and influence, they use very different grammar and written scripts. Southerners see language as a key cultural identifier & a core part of their identity.

Thus, there are often arguments on whether India should have a national language [it doesn't have any]. In the north, Hindi [a Sanskritized Hindusthani language] is often pushed as the national connector, while the south pushes back due to the point above. Language is a very hot button issue in the south. The linguistic factor has led some of the southern regions voting for regional parties than the national ones, since the 1970s.

Differences in diet

North India is in subtropical zone and bordering temperate zone, while the south India is in the tropical zone. Apart from latitude, north India is also more likely to be cooler due to the absence of ocean and the proximity to the Himalayas. Like in the case of China, the northerners tend to include more of wheat in their diet, while the southerners primarily eat rice. Again, like in the case of China, the spice levels tend to increase as you move towards the south. [Of course, some parts of north India like Rajasthan tend to have much higher spice levels than some parts of south India like Karnataka]

Why are there so many differences between the architecture of North Indian temples and South Indian temples?

North Indian temples look partly like mosques due to intermingling and assimilitation of Islamic arts.

Deepak Nautiyal
Creator Author has 260 answers and 42.7K answer views Fri

North Indian and South Indian Hindu temples are distinct in their architectural style and features. North Indian temples typically have a square or rectangular shape with a domed roof and multiple entrances, while South Indian temples are characterized by towering gopurams, ornate entrance gateways, and intricate pillared mandapas.

Another notable difference is the use of material. North Indian temples are commonly made of red sandstone or marble, while South Indian temples are constructed of granite or soapstone, which is easier to carve into intricate designs.

The worship practices and rituals

North Indian and South Indian Hindu temples are distinct in their architectural style and features. North Indian temples typically have a square or rectangular shape with a domed roof and multiple entrances, while South Indian temples are characterized by towering gopurams, ornate entrance gateways, and intricate pillared mandapas.

Another notable difference is the use of material. North Indian temples are commonly made of red sandstone or marble, while South Indian temples are constructed of granite or soapstone, which is easier to carve into intricate designs.

The worship practices and rituals also differ between the two regions. In North Indian temples, devotees offer flowers, fruits, and sweets to the deities and perform aarti, a ritual of waving a flame in front of the idol. South Indian temples, on the other hand, have a more elaborate worship system, where devotees offer a variety of items such as coconut, betel leaves, and rice, and follow specific rituals for each deity.

The language used for prayers and hymns also varies. North Indian temples use Hindi or other regional languages, while South Indian temples use Tamil, Telugu, Kannada, or Malayalam.

Overall, North Indian and South Indian temples have distinct architectural, worship, and language differences that reflect the rich diversity of Hindu culture in India.
